description.narrative: The overarching goal of the project is to save energy and to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases by increasing energy efficiency of municipal lighting in the cities of Armenia via implementation of municipal investment programs and national policies

activity-description.narrative: To save energy and to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases by increasing the energy efficiency (EE) of municipal lighting in the cities of Armenia via the implementation of municipal investment programs and national policies.

description.narrative: Demonstration projects Pilot projects yield costeffective energy savings raising the confidence and capacity of investors and decisionmakers about EE lighting

Efficiency and energy savings of installed EE lighting
Share of LED in demoprojects

comment.narrative:
The majority of fixtures in municipal outdoor lighting sector incorporate inefficient 250W HPS lamps or 400W mercuryvapor lamps
The indoor lighting sector is dominated by inefficient incandescent lamps and fluorescent tubes

At least five demonstration projects on a number of efficient lighting technologies completed for indoor outdoor and street lighting
Direct energy savings of up to 095 GWh per year by completion of all pilots subject to final selection of pilot size and technologies 100 LED for outdoor park and indoor lighting pilots 40 LED included in street lighting pilots

3 demonstration projects are completed
In Yerevan 482 street LED luminaires were procured and installed on the road connecting the citys center with Zvartnots international airport 9 km replacing high pressure sodium lamps with 63 energy efficiency improvement
In Yerevan Zoological Garden 115 park LED luminaires were procured and installed as a part of full reconstruction of the lighting system
In Alaverdi 70 street LED were installed with 55 procured by the project and 15 by the partner NGO FrenchArmenian interprofessional network
100 LED replacement is achieved in all the three implemented demonstration projects

At least five demonstration projects on a number of efficient lighting technologies completed for indoor outdoor and street lighting
Direct energy savings of up to 095 GWh per year by completion of all pilots subject to final selection of pilot size and technologies 100 LED for outdoor park and indoor lighting pilots 40 LED included in street lighting pilots

3 demonstration projects are completed
In Yerevan 482 street LED luminaires were procured and installed on the road connecting the citys center with Zvartnots international airport 9 km replacing high pressure sodium lamps with 63 energy efficiency improvement
In Yerevan Zoological Garden 115 park LED luminaires were procured and installed as a part of full reconstruction of the lighting system
In Alaverdi 70 street LED were installed with 55 procured by the project and 15 by the partner NGO FrenchArmenian interprofessional network
100 LED replacement is achieved in all the three implemented demonstration projects

description.narrative: Municipal energy audits and technical capacitybuilding

Methodology for energylighting audit
Number of municipal energy audits conducted
Number of specialists and agency representatives trained
Public media exposure

comment.narrative:
Lack of methodology for assessing the feasibility financial and technical of an energy efficient lighting technology upgrade
Comprehensive energy audits are not part of normal practice for public lighting in Armenia
No specialized training on EE lighting is offered in Armenia
Limited broadcasting of information on EE lighting

By the project midterm the methodology will be established and shared with municipalities
At least 10 comprehensive audits of public lighting completed in Yerevan and other cities
Training on EE lighting delivered to specialists and agency representatives in Yerevan and at least 10 other cities
Media releases on outcomes of each pilot Awareness raising materials available for general public

The methodology was developed and tested during energy audit in Yerevan city demo site Alaverdi Stepanavan Spitak and Goris towns Total 5 audits
30 specialists were trained of Yerevan Municipal Illumination Company and respective municipalities on proper installation and operation and maintenance of lightemitting diodes LED luminaires
Seminar on technical regulation of lighting devices application and establishment of national testing laboratory was held by a specialists of a partner to the project Center of LED and optoelectronic technologies of National Academy of Sciences of Belarus 50 participants
Awareness raising materials prepared and disseminated including sharing during relevant events

By the project midterm the methodology will be established and shared with municipalities
At least 10 comprehensive audits of public lighting completed in Yerevan and other cities
Training on EE lighting delivered to specialists and agency representatives in Yerevan and at least 10 other cities
Media releases on outcomes of each pilot Awareness raising materials available for general public

The methodology was developed and tested during energy audit in Yerevan city demo site Alaverdi Stepanavan Spitak and Goris towns Total 5 audits
30 specialists were trained of Yerevan Municipal Illumination Company and respective municipalities on proper installation and operation and maintenance of lightemitting diodes LED luminaires
Seminar on technical regulation of lighting devices application and establishment of national testing laboratory was held by a specialists of a partner to the project Center of LED and optoelectronic technologies of National Academy of Sciences of Belarus 50 participants
Awareness raising materials prepared and disseminated including sharing during relevant events

description.narrative: National policies codes and standards on lighting New national policies mandate significantly greater energy efficiency and ensure product quality for lighting particularly in residential buildings
Existence of regulations that mandate improved energy efficiency of lighting products and installations including codes standards and procurement rules

comment.narrative:
Conventional incandescent lighting is available without restrictions and constitutes 85 percent of residential lighting in Armenia
There is no regulation on energy performance of lighting products in Armenia

Proposed improvement to existing legislation addressing minimum energy performance requirements for lighting appliances
A national phaseout plan of conventional incandescent lighting is adopted
Other adopted policies and supporting standards
New criteria including performance and life cycle costs for incorporation in state procurement procedures for lighting applications are developed

The energy labeling procedure economy sector identification by its energyintensity concept for further use in statistics and a number of other amendments after discussion were included in the amendments to the RA Law On Renewable Energy and Energy Saving currently pending adoption by the National Assembly of the RA
The decision of RA Government as developed by the project On implementation of energy saving and energy efficiency improvement measures in objects being constructed reconstructed renovated under the state funding was approved by the Government of the RA decision 1504N of December 25 2014
International experience on phaseout of inefficient incandescent lamps was studied and a respective analytical note was elaborated including an address to legal and regulatory issues

Proposed improvement to existing legislation addressing minimum energy performance requirements for lighting appliances
A national phaseout plan of conventional incandescent lighting is adopted
Other adopted policies and supporting standards
New criteria including performance and life cycle costs for incorporation in state procurement procedures for lighting applications are developed

The energy labeling procedure economy sector identification by its energyintensity concept for further use in statistics and a number of other amendments after discussion were included in the amendments to the RA Law On Renewable Energy and Energy Saving currently pending adoption by the National Assembly of the RA
The decision of RA Government as developed by the project On implementation of energy saving and energy efficiency improvement measures in objects being constructed reconstructed renovated under the state funding was approved by the Government of the RA decision 1504N of December 25 2014
International experience on phaseout of inefficient incandescent lamps was studied and a respective analytical note was elaborated including an address to legal and regulatory issues

description.narrative:
Replication via municipal programs and associated financial instruments
Municipal lighting programs lead to widespread deployment of EE lighting and associated energy savings

Municipal programs for EE public lighting
Financial commitments for energyefficient municipal lighting

comment.narrative: Municipal programs for EE public lighting are desired but not comprehensively designed financed or implemented

Municipality of Yerevan develops and adopts program for upgrades of municipal lighting
Similar programs are adopted in other cities of Armenia
Savings of 20 GWh per year from municipal lighting programs
US 10 million for energyefficient municipal lighting secured
Establishment of financing mechanisms for Yerevan and other municipalities eg revolving fund from savings achieved from piloted EE measures
Support in preparation of funding proposals including tenders for ESCOs for cities of Armenia

Municipal programs for Alaverdi Spitak Goris and Stepanavan towns are drafted Alaverdi and Spitak drafts are shared with the owner municipalities for comments and further approval
Revolving fund concept operation procedure and financial flow estimation methodology are developed discussed approved and at work in Yerevan In Alaverdi the revolving fund concept is under consideration

Municipality of Yerevan develops and adopts program for upgrades of municipal lighting
Similar programs are adopted in other cities of Armenia
Savings of 20 GWh per year from municipal lighting programs
US 10 million for energyefficient municipal lighting secured
Establishment of financing mechanisms for Yerevan and other municipalities eg revolving fund from savings achieved from piloted EE measures
Support in preparation of funding proposals including tenders for ESCOs for cities of Armenia

Municipal programs for Alaverdi Spitak Goris and Stepanavan towns are drafted Alaverdi and Spitak drafts are shared with the owner municipalities for comments and further approval
Revolving fund concept operation procedure and financial flow estimation methodology are developed discussed approved and at work in Yerevan In Alaverdi the revolving fund concept is under consideration

description.narrative: To remove barriers to energyefficient lighting in Armenia by means of technical assessment facilitation of financing and development and implementation of municipal programs and national policy
Quantity of energy saved and GHG emissions avoided

comment.narrative:
Street lighting 40 GWh of electricity consumed for street lighting in 2011 accounting for about 16000 tons of CO2 emissions
Average fixture power consumption is 210W in 2011
Residential lighting 550 GWh consumed for residential lighting in 2011 accounting for about 220000 tons of CO2 emissions

Direct energy savings of 12 GWh per year from demonstration projects 474 tonnes of CO2 emissions
Indirect energy savings of 20 GWh per year from replication of demonstration projects via municipal programs 8000 tonnes of CO2 emissions
Indirect energy savings of 125 GWh per year from implementation of national lighting policy 50000 tonnes of CO2 emissions

Direct energy savings achieved within the reporting period from demonstration projects is 1276 MWh 91 and 566 tonnes of CO2 emissions
Indirect energy saving from replication of demonstration projects is expected to be achieved within the next reporting period
Indirect energy saving from implementation of national lighting policy is expected to be achieved by the end of the project

Direct energy savings of 12 GWh per year from demonstration projects 474 tonnes of CO2 emissions
Indirect energy savings of 20 GWh per year from replication of demonstration projects via municipal programs 8000 tonnes of CO2 emissions
Indirect energy savings of 125 GWh per year from implementation of national lighting policy 50000 tonnes of CO2 emissions

Direct energy savings achieved within the reporting period from demonstration projects is 1276 MWh 91 and 566 tonnes of CO2 emissions
Indirect energy saving from replication of demonstration projects is expected to be achieved within the next reporting period
Indirect energy saving from implementation of national lighting policy is expected to be achieved by the end of the project

description.narrative: 1.1. Availability of methodology for energy/lighting audit 1.2. Availability of outputs of conducted energy audits for the municipal lighting systems of all the urban areas/cities that had officially applied and requested those 1.3. Availability of consistent and continuous training for specialists and agency representatives both as officially requested and within the thematic events 1.4. Level of the project's public outreach/media exposure 2.1. Level of upgrade in efficiency and energy savings of installed energy efficient lighting in selected buildings 2.2. Level of upgrade in the share of light-emitting diodes in demo-projects 3.1. Availability of developed municipal programs for energy efficient public lighting 3.2. Availability of confirmed financial commitments for energy-efficient municipal lighting 4.1. Availability of developed regulations that mandate improved energy efficiency of lighting products and installations

comment.narrative: 1.1. Lack of methodology for assessing energy efficiency in lighting (2013) 1.2. Municipalities are not aware of energy saving potential in lighting sector (2013) 1.3. No specialized training or training materials on energy efficient lighting is offered in Armenia (2013) 1.4. Limited broadcasting of information on energy efficient lighting (2013) 2.1. The majority of fixtures in municipal street lighting sector incorporate inefficient 250 Watt high-pressure sodium lamps or 400 Watt mercury-vapor lamps (2013) 2.2. The majority of fixtures in municipal street lighting sector incorporate inefficient 250 Watt high-pressure sodium lamps or 400 Watt mercury-vapor lamps (2013) 3.1. Municipal programs for energy efficient public lighting are desired but not comprehensively designed, financed, or implemented (2013) 3.2. Municipal programs for energy efficient public lighting are desired but not comprehensively designed, financed, or implemented (2013) 4.1. There is no regulation on energy performance of lighting products in Armenia (2013)

1. Revision of the road construction norm's lighting section. 2. Monitoring of the demo projects and supporting the municipalities in planning the extension works. 3. Continuing support to the testing of luminaries and lamps in the laboratory. 4. Support the design institutions in applying new construction norms for proper light design for schools and kindergartens. 5. Launch the new publication "Green Lighting" bilingual textbook, conducting open lessons in the two profile universities and distribution of the textbook to laboratories and users. 6. Selection of the Independent Technical Evaluator for conducting project's terminal evaluation to be completed by June 2018. 7. Lessons learned report prepared and distributed by a month before the end of the project. 8. Trainings, seminars, awareness campaigns, including two-day retreat/training on Scaling the Energy Efficiency in lighting sector for municipalities representatives.

Annual: 1. The road construction norm's lighting section in circulation, consultations rendered upon request. 2. Monitoring of the demo projects ongoing, issues in planning the extension works addressed per municipalities' requests. 3. Testing of luminaries and lamps in the laboratory supported continuously. 4. Support rendered to the design institutions upon their requests. 5. "Green Lighting" bilingual textbook is published, dissemination underway. 6. Terminal Evaluation that graded the project's activities and progress as "highly satisfactory" with its Management Response are available via https://erc.undp.org/evaluation/evaluations/detail/8396. 7. Lessons Learned Report developed in English, translated into Armenian and printed out for dissemination among key partners and stakeholders. 8. The Concluding seminar of the project, one training and one presentation of a public opinion survey findings are held.
Quarter 3: 1. Consultations rendered upon request on application of the road construction norm's lighting section previously revised, approved by the Ministry of Urban Development and circulated. 2. Monitoring of the demo projects ongoing, issues in planning the extension works addressed per municipalities' requests. 3. Testing of luminaries and lamps in the laboratory supported continuously. 4. Support rendered to the design institutions upon their requests. 5. "Green Lighting" bilingual textbook in its final stage of preparation to publication. 6. Management response prepared per the completed Terminal Evaluation that graded the project's activities and progress as "highly satisfactory". 7. Lessons Learned Report development close to completion. 8. One training and one presentation of a public opinion survey findings are held.
Semi-annual: 1. The road construction norm's lighting section revised, approved by the Ministry of Urban Development and circulated. 2. Monitoring of the demo projects ongoing, issues in planning the extension works addressed per municipalities' requests. 3. Testing of luminaries and lamps in the laboratory supported continuously. 4. Support rendered to the design institutions upon their requests. 5. "Green Lighting" bilingual textbook is partially sent to the publishing house for make-up and page-proof. 6. Terminal Evaluation completed, the project's activities and progress graded as "highly satisfactory". 7. Lessons Learned Report development underway based on the prepared outline. 8. One training held, planning of more trainings, seminars, awareness campaigns is underway.
Quarter 1: 1. Revision of the road construction norm's lighting section initiated. 2. Monitoring of the demo projects ongoing, issues in planning the extension works addressed per municipalities' requests. 3. Testing of luminaries and lamps in the laboratory supported continuously. 4. Support rendered to the design institutions upon their requests. 5. The new publication "Green Lighting" bilingual textbook is in preparation for publication. 6. Selection of the Independent Technical Evaluator for conducting project's terminal evaluation is in process. 7. Outline of Lessons Learned Report prepared. 8. Planning of trainings, seminars, awareness campaigns is underway.
